title: 107_s2079
content: The curr_chunk is about judicial review of the adoption or revision of a schedule of ratings for disabilities. The text of section 502 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to allow judicial review of actions by the Secretary related to the adoption or revision of the schedule of ratings for disabilities. Review can be sought in the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in accordance with specific provisions. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit can review and set aside actions related to the adoption or revision of the schedule of ratings for disabilities if they are found to be arbitrary, capricious, or in violation of statutory right. This amendment takes effect upon enactment and applies to revisions of the schedule of ratings occurring after that date. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can reverse erroneous findings of fact by the Board of Veterans' Appeals. The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims can reverse findings of fact by the Board of Veterans' Appeals if not supported by evidence. Amendments include specifying the scope of authority and matters relating to findings of material fact. The amendments specify the process for making determinations on findings of material fact in appeals filed with the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. The amendments will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. The amendments specify the process for making determinations on findings of material fact in appeals filed with the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims, either before or after the enactment of the Act. The amendment allows the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit to review decisions of the Court of Veterans Appeals on rules of law. It applies to appeals filed after the enactment of the Act or pending appeals without a final decision. The amendment grants the Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims the authority to award fees and expenses to non-attorney practitioners under the Equal Access to Justice Act as if they were attorneys admitted to practice before the Court.
